content: How can I help you today?

I'm honestly not sure if you can. My wife insisted I come here, and I guess I don’t know where to start. Things at home are a mess, and it feels like everything is falling apart. I’m just overwhelmed.

It sounds like there's been a lot on your plate, and feeling overwhelmed can be really difficult to work through. It took a lot of strength to show up today, especially when things feel so heavy. Would you like to start by sharing a little more about what's been going on at home, or what feels most overwhelming right now?

I guess it's everything. My wife and I have been arguing a lot, mostly about how to deal with my son. He's been acting out a lot lately, and nothing we try seems to work. It’s like we’re constantly walking on eggshells, and it’s gotten to the point where it’s affecting our relationship and how I feel about myself. I just feel like I’m failing everywhere—in my marriage, my family, and even at work.

That sounds incredibly heavy—trying to be there for your son, your wife, and managing all the other pressures you're feeling. It makes sense that it would start to feel like you're carrying more than you can handle. Feeling like you're not succeeding in those areas must be really tough, especially when you care so much about your family and your role in it. What do you think has been the hardest part for you in all of this?

I think the hardest part is feeling like I’m failing my family. No matter what I do, it doesn’t seem to get better. My son is struggling so much, my wife and I are drifting apart, and I don’t even feel present for my daughter. It’s like I’m losing everything, and I don’t know how to fix it.

It sounds like there's a deep sense of responsibility weighing on you, and it's hard not knowing how to make things better. You're holding so much concern for your family, and that shows how much they mean to you. Even though it feels like things are slipping away right now, the fact that you're here, talking about it, says a lot about how much you care and want to make things better. Where do you think you’d like to start—either for yourself or for your family?

I'm not sure where to start. Maybe... I just want to feel like I'm making progress somewhere. I want to help my son, but I don't even know how, and I feel stuck. And maybe if I could figure that out, other things might start getting better too. I just don't know if that's even possible.

It sounds like helping your son is really important to you, and you’re searching for a way to move forward, even if it feels uncertain right now. That desire to support him and make progress shows how much you care. Maybe we could explore what “progress” might look like for you when it comes to helping him—what do you think would feel like a success, even a small one?

It sounds like you’re doing your best in a tough situation, and that desire to help shows how invested you are in your family. Starting with small steps might help—it doesn’t have to all be fixed at once. Do you feel like you have a sense of what your son might need right now, or do you think it could help to explore that more together?

It seems like you care deeply about figuring out what your son needs, and that's already a significant step. Sometimes the hardest part is untangling those feelings of being stuck and knowing where to begin. What do you think might be going on with your son right now, or what have you noticed that makes you feel concerned?

I honestly have no idea what he needs right now. He’s angry all the time, and I don’t even know why. He yells, he doesn’t listen, and it’s like he’s constantly trying to push boundaries no matter what we do. It’s exhausting, and I don’t know how to reach him anymore.

It sounds like you’ve been trying so hard to connect with him, but his anger and behavior seem to be building walls. Feeling exhausted and unsure of how to reach him can take a big toll—on your energy, your patience, and even your confidence as a parent. If you don’t mind sharing, have there been moments where you’ve been able to connect with him, even briefly? Or things you’ve tried in the past that seemed to work, even for a little while?

It sounds like you’ve been trying so hard to connect with him, but his anger and behavior seem to be building walls. Feeling exhausted and unsure of how to reach him can take a big toll—on your energy, your patience, and even your confidence as a parent. If you don’t mind sharing, have there been moments where you’ve been able to connect with him, even briefly? Or things you’ve tried in the past that seemed to work, even for a little while?

It takes so much effort to navigate the challenges you're facing as a parent, and you're showing real strength just by considering different approaches. Reconnecting with even small, positive moments can sometimes offer clues about what works. Do you think reflecting on recent interactions—positive or not—might help you understand what’s driving his behavior or how you might approach things differently?

I honestly can’t think of any recent moments where we’ve really connected. It’s like everything turns into a fight before it even gets going. I’ve tried talking to him one-on-one, doing activities he used to like, or even just giving him space, but nothing seems to help. I feel like I’m always guessing and just failing at it.

That sounds incredibly frustrating—to try so many approaches and still feel like you’re not breaking through. It sounds like you’ve really been putting in an effort to connect with him, even though the outcomes haven’t been what you hoped for. It’s normal to feel discouraged when it feels like you’re guessing without results. What do you think might be most helpful for you personally in this situation—to have a clearer direction, gain support from others, or maybe take some space to regroup?

It sounds so hard to feel like nothing is working despite all your efforts. It’s clear that you care so much about your son, and it’s not easy to show up the way you want to when nothing feels effective. Maybe we can figure out some small, specific steps or even uncover what might be going on beneath his behavior—are there any patterns you’ve noticed about when or why he might act out the way he does?

You're doing your best to understand and support him, even when it feels like you’re hitting a wall, and that says a lot about how committed you are as a parent. Exploring those patterns could be a way to gain some insight—do you ever notice certain triggers or situations that seem to spark his anger or frustration? Or maybe there’s been a recent change in his routine, friendships, or environment that could be affecting him?

You're right; it’s really tough to figure out what’s underneath it all when everything just feels chaotic. I think a lot of his outbursts happen when we ask him to do something he doesn’t want to do or when he doesn’t get his way. But that’s nothing new—he’s just more intense about it now. I don’t know if something specific set this off, or if he’s just always going to be like this. I worry I’m not doing enough to help him figure out how to manage it.

It seems like you’re really trying to understand him and support him in a meaningful way, while also managing your own worry about whether it's enough. Noticing patterns in his outbursts, like around limits or expectations, is already a helpful observation—it shows how much you’re paying attention even in this tough time. How do you think he responds when you try to talk with him during calmer moments? Or do those opportunities feel rare right now?
